On today's show: @jehadibnsaleem  and @Budour48 give updates on the violence unfolding in Gaza. Plus, psychologist @PosnerKelly explains suicide warning signs, causes and prevention mechanisms. Listen: https://t.co/o6ezqrpj5F

Palestinian scholar @jehadibnsaleem says the violence in Gaza can't be disconnected from Palestinian struggles in the West Bank, inside Israel and in the diaspora. "When we talk about violence, we're talking about decades and decades of violence ... inflicted on Palestinians." https://t.co/K41GSYcEAG

Psychiatry professor @PosnerKelly encourages doctors to incorporate conversations about suicide into routine primary care treatment: "We often assume that they're gonna have the will to come to us. And they often don't. That's why we need to come to them." https://t.co/7X1b5moMFW

"We don't think of depression like we think of cancer," says @PosnerKelly of @C_SSRS. "Because people don't think of this as a medical illness … it prevents them from actually getting the lifesaving medications and care and treatment that they need." https://t.co/2bLDwdnkOI
The national suicide prevention hotline is 1-800-273-TALK (8255) and more resources are available at https://t.co/hMXm2MYqQv. https://t.co/1q9s9Vy2Jz

Kelly Posner Gerstenhaber (@PosnerKelly) says there has been “a slow and steady rise” in suicides, about 1% per year over the last three decades. The good news, she says, is that suicide is preventable. https://t.co/4hW4W01z3d

Budour Hassan, who is a Palestinian citizen of Israel, says she will boycott the Israeli election. “I believe participating in these elections is only going to grant Israel legitimacy and promote its image as some sort of democratic haven when it is anything but," she says. https://t.co/gkNMxmhDzV

Jehad Abusalim (@jehadibnsaleem) says the international community needs to go beyond issuing condemnations of the U.S. and Israel: "It's about time to go beyond these narratives and to challenge the negative role the U.S. has played, and to hold Israel accountable." https://t.co/KQQZImITZi

"What's been happening in the Golan Heights is inseparable from Israel's broader policies of seizing Arab and Palestinian land and continuing to control these lands," says @jehadibnsaleem, who notes the voices have of the people who live here have been "rendered unheard." https://t.co/XVeYQXlUTE

Palestinian activist @Budour48 of @AdvocacyJlac says what's missing from the coverage of Trump's Golan Heights announcement are the voices of people who actually live there. "Their land is Syrian. It's not disputed land, it's not a contested land, it's a Syrian land." https://t.co/BzfoEvIUSt

THEN– After two Parkland survivors died by suicide last week, the father of a 6-year-old girl who was killed in the Sandy Hook shootings died in an apparent suicide Monday. We'll speak with @PosnerKelly about the public health crisis of suicide, 8-9AM ET: https://t.co/Xup8cdtnFB https://t.co/BoHFDcDCTT

TODAY: Israeli airstrikes hit Gaza for the third day in a row after militants inside the territory launched rockets at Israel. For the latest, we'll speak with Jehad Abusalim (@jehadibnsaleem) and Budour Hassan (@Budour48). Watch 8-9AM ET: https://t.co/Xup8cdtnFB https://t.co/H9pgQQlCgb

Miss the debate between  @theintercept’s @ggreenwald and @DCReportMedia’s @DavidCayJ on the outcome of the Mueller report? Listen to the podcast: https://t.co/8vaAp8PkXQ

Journalist @ggreenwald calls suggestions that Trump is beholden to Vladimir Putin an irresponsible claim that has ratcheted up tensions between the U.S. and Russia. "The whole thing has been a joke and a fairy tale from the start." https://t.co/hScUgA5bYw

Journalist @ggreenwald compares reckoning with the Mueller report conclusions to learning there were no Iraqi WMDs in 2003: "It's time to face the truth. The media got the story wrong. … All this time there was no evidence for it. It was just a conspiracy theory." https://t.co/dP2YIF4AEK

"We should have focused much more on Donald Trump's not fulfilling his promises," says @DavidCayJ of the intense media focus on Russian collusion, for which the Mueller report has found no evidence. He says there is a "limited audience" for topics related to "governance." https://t.co/uVprUaGmpf

2/2 "...continue to try to cling to some vestige of credibility by continuing to spin conspiracy theories that are even more reckless and even more unhinged than the ones to which we've been subjected for three years."

.@ggreenwald says the Mueller report concludes "the saddest media spectacle I've ever seen." 

"What makes it even sadder is to watch all of the people who vested their journalistic credibility into what proved to be a complete and total fraud and scam..." 1/2 https://t.co/YrwHuJZu7g

"We don't know what's in the Mueller report," says @DavidCayJ. "We only know the brief interpretation offered by [Attorney General] Bill Barr." He says the full report must be publicly released. https://t.co/18YGkN5Eif

THEN: We celebrate two remarkable figures who have just celebrated their 100th birthdays:  legendary peace activist Frances Crowe & leading literary figure of the Beat Generation Lawrence Ferlinghetti. Stream live 8-9AM ET: https://t.co/Xup8cdtnFB. https://t.co/UEOg04O9y7

Nick Estes (@nick_w_estes) of the Lower Brule Sioux Tribe links the Green New Deal to resistance at Standing Rock. "The United States, along with countries like Canada, drilled their way out of the Great Recession — largely at the expense of indigenous lands," he says. https://t.co/z6yyZ5GtGR

"When we talk about … the massive flooding that's happening in places like Southeastern Africa, we can connect it to the oil production in the United States," says @nick_w_estes. He adds that climate catastrophe "affects indigenous communities first and foremost." https://t.co/aJDGrP3iCu

.@nick_w_estes links flooding in the Midwest to long-running environmental destruction: "While it is related to climate change in the present, it's also related to the altering of the environment, specifically of the river ecosystem to provide flood control in the first place." https://t.co/ES6o3cqjV0

"We really need to strengthen the narrative of equity and of historical responsibility within the climate strikes, within the Green New Deal. I think there are wonderful opportunities, but we need to remember the South." —Dipti Bhatnagar (@diptimoz) of @FoEint https://t.co/EBYsrC2ayu

Dipti Bhatnagar (@diptimoz) says the cyclone that hit southern Africa is the kind of extreme weather event intensified by the climate crisis. "In Mozambique, we knew this was going to be our fate, that as the oceans warm ... this is going to have a direct impact on our people." https://t.co/pwz68DhDID

"Our communities, our people are getting battered from all sides by this disaster," says Dipti Bhatnagar ( @diptimoz), a Mozambique-based climate justice activist, on Cyclone Idai's destruction in southern Africa. https://t.co/SzYoIjmg4S

Multiple Israeli candidates for office have run campaign ads promising violence against Palestinians, with one vowing to "bomb Gaza back to the Stone Age" if elected. Responding to these ads, human rights attorney @4noura says: "Welcome to Israel. Welcome to Palestinian lives." https://t.co/P9IIRJ0Jfg

Noura Erakat (@4noura) says Trump's supporters care less about regional stability in the Middle East and more about "seeing Israel establishing itself as a hegemon within an Islamophobic framework, which positions israel as the easternmost front of the U.S.'s war on terror." https://t.co/BolcrUd0lP

.@4noura on Trump's announcement that the U.S. will recognize the Golan Heights for Israel: "If we see the international community stand in opposition, then the U.S.'s declaration will be merely that — a declaration, where the U.S. is a lone figure in the rest of the world." https://t.co/L0FOveRoeL

"Israel is not interested in the Golan Heights for security. If it were interested in that, then it wouldn't be settling its civilians there," says Palestinian human rights attorney Noura Erakat (@4noura). She adds, "There is no military threat to Israel from that border." https://t.co/QWMYlOF6WZ

Also: The Midwestern U.S. is beginning to address the unprecedented flooding that hit the region this week, including 4 tribal nations in Nebraska. We're joined by @nick_w_estes to discuss how the flooding impacts indigenous communities, 8-9AM ET: https://t.co/Xup8cdtnFB. https://t.co/vdOKzr5K9Y

"The people bearing the brunt of the tragedy in the war in Somalia is not soldiers on either side," says @Brian_Castner of @amnesty. "It is the civilians who are trapped on one side—Al-Shabaab on one side, airstrikes, and other military operations on the other." https://t.co/zD6PQpYVhu

"Jared's peace plan is essentially Bibi's peace plan—it involves everyone else doing things and everyone else paying for it except Israel." https://t.co/BwXCtAKit3

Journalist @VickyPJWard calls Kushner's behind-the-scenes business dealings "diplomacy in the dark." 

"The idea that Jared is running around doing all of this, and nobody knows anything about it, not even our state department, not national security council — that's horrifying." https://t.co/yDIIW9Wy4g

Jared Kushner and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman formed a bond that "really alarmed" former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and former Secretary of Defense James Mattis, says journalist @VickyPJWard. "Jared and MBS cut out all the national security officials." https://t.co/ibA2K8vZZW

Investigative journalist @VickyPJWard says the Kushner family is desperate to pay off its New York skyscraper at 666 Fifth Avenue, calling it an "albatross."

"Haiti is going through a terrible uprising in large measure because the support that Venezuela provided Haiti—$4.3 billion of cheap oil and cheap credit—has finished," says journalist @kimives13 of @ haiti_liberte. https://t.co/RXzi8phvTG

The brazen operation is detailed in a new report by @kimives13 of @haiti_liberte and @matthewacole of @theintercept: "U.S. mercenaries arrested in Haiti were part of a half-baked scheme to move $80 million for embattled president" https://t.co/YJQQLfwKlQ

"It was completely illegal," says @kimives13, on the release of 5 heavily armed Americans who were arrested when they were found with a cache of weapons near Haiti's central bank, then were quickly released. "They should've been charged with illegally exporting arms." https://t.co/Vkm1rOfejL

There is "a lot of political pressure" for @USAfricaCommand to not appear at war, says @Brian_Castner of @amnesty. "Some of those are from the American people. After 18 years, the country is war weary. It doesn't want to hear that there's another war." https://t.co/DaNEQkgVjL

Amnesty International's @Brian_Castner questions U.S. military figures about civilian deaths from airstrikes in Somalia: "110 strikes, 800 terrorists killed, 0 civilians—we would maintain that in war nothing is perfect, so going 800 for 800 is just not a reasonable conclusion." https://t.co/19BYpRyxes

https://t.co/0PNopmvzDT

"In the popular imagination, 1890 was the endpoint" of Native peoples, says @DavidTreuer. His book "The Heartbeat of Wounded Knee: Native America from 1890 to the Present," counters that narrative. "I'm not destroyed, my culture isn't destroyed, my community isn't destroyed." https://t.co/4PAnDyc7BX

"You have the president making light and being flippantly dehumanizing and offensive about our genocide," says @ChaseIronEyes. "You know, my family literally survived Wounded Knee. When he says the things he does, he gives license to young impressionable minds" https://t.co/nu33P8PgDG

"I was very concerned that it was going to get out of hand," @ChaseIronEyes adds, on Saturday's confrontation near the Lincoln Memorial. "And I looked for adults—If they were there, they were wearing MAGA hats, too, and encouraging this" https://t.co/MzgQvkUDJP

.@ChaseIronEyes, who helped organize the Indigenous People's March, recounts what he saw: "There were so many youth, jumping up and down, jeering. It was a mob frenzy, they were ridiculing, they were exhibiting nothing but contempt and scorn for one of our elders" https://t.co/xZvsHRaKC9

"I was absolutely afraid. There was a group of over 200 young, angry white men who were displaying mob mentality, and they were facing down just four black individuals," says Nathan Phillips.
